name: NPR
text:
President Trump says he will create a commission to promote "patriotic education" as well as a grant to develop a "pro-American curriculum."

The federal government does not have jurisdiction over school curriculum.
https://t.co/VGwI2TY0V1

name: NPR
text: Today on #NPRConsiderthis, campaigns and political parties have staffed up their legal war rooms, making this campaign season one of the most litigated ever.  We look at the lawsuits already filed and what might come next. https://t.co/tu29AyYbGL

name: NPR
text:
The postmaster general, in a "tense" call with top U.S. election officials, said his agency is equipped to handle the expected increase in mail volume during this election season.
https://t.co/zLwIC5p1U7

name: NPR
text:
President Trump on Thursday decried what he said was a "twisted web of lies" being taught in U.S. classrooms about systemic racism in America ‚Äî and called it "a form of child abuse."
https://t.co/MfWzpyJm30

name: NPR
text:
The Scientific American has endorsed Joe Biden ‚Äî the magazine's first-ever presidential endorsement in its 175-year history.

"We need to tell what we know about the consequences the Trump administration has had for science," its editor-in-chief says.
https://t.co/LYMZtCDZrZ

name: NPR
text:
Educators around the U.S. are facing heartbreaking choices between the needs of their students and the needs of their own children.

"I have never worked harder in my life, the level of mental fatigue is tremendous."
https://t.co/v8m39qrjlE

name: NPR
text:
Nearly 30 Massachusetts high school students have been told to quarantine after one student's parents sent their teenager to school despite knowing they tested positive for the coronavirus.
https://t.co/aBap0EzwDf

name: NPR
text:
The WHO says weekly coronavirus cases in Europe are rising at a higher rate than during the pandemic's peak in March, with "alarming rates of transmission across the region."
https://t.co/wScLGOEcF3

name: NPR
text:
RT @MorningEdition: Breonna Taylor's name has become a rallying cry in protests against racial injustice.

While the police who killed Taylor in March have not been charged, her family received a settlement this week in a wrongful death lawsuit.

Her mother Tamika Palmer talks to @rachelnpr: https://t.co/ffnxKdrrXPBreonna Taylor's name has become a rallying cry in protests against racial injustice.

While the police who killed‚Ä¶ https://t.co/Lk9wvSEQfu

name: NPR
text:
President Trump and Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden are both traveling to Minnesota today, as the contested state begins its early voting period.
https://t.co/JuWQDj2PVN

name: NPR
text:
A new NPR poll shows households of color have been hardest hit financially by COVID-19.

Percentages of households that report facing "serious financial problems" during the pandemic:
-Latino: 72%
-Black: 60%
-Native American: 55%
-Asian: 37%
-White: 36%
https://t.co/2KUr3Q9ZcU

name: NPR
text:
Breonna Taylor's mother, Tamika Palmer, says she hopes the officers who killed her daughter in March will be fired and arrested. A decision on whether to bring charges is expected in the coming days.
https://t.co/cZAVauEDlo

name: NPR
text:
President Trump and Joe Biden are both traveling to Minnesota on Friday, as the state begins its early voting period.

The Trump campaign has its eyes on flipping the state. But recent polls show Biden with a clear lead.
https://t.co/uwkyrKfVgR

name: NPR
text:
A new NPR poll shows Black, Latino and Native American households have been hardest hit by the financial impact of the coronavirus crisis.

And it could have lasting effects ‚Äî worsening the country's existing racial wealth gap.
https://t.co/vXX2brgdaB

name: NPR
text:
There are still a lot of things up in the air, with less than two months before Election Day.

And amid a pandemic and dozens of ongoing legal fights over voting rules, election workers are doing what they can to adjust ‚Äî and to help voters keep up.
https://t.co/jgb3vl3ovk

name: NPR
text:
Just weeks ago, Kenya was girding itself for the worst. The country went from a peak of more than 600 new coronavirus cases a day in August ‚Äî to fewer than 100 the past few days.

Now, researchers are trying to figure out what happened.
https://t.co/LaIgcg3t8s

name: NPR
text:
In response to the coronavirus, dozens of states have modified their rules for absentee voting in November's elections.

Here's a map looking at mail-in voting procedures for each state üëá
https://t.co/RbHo5A5yvA

name: NPR
text: The head of the U.N.‚Äôs World Food Program is asking the world's billionaires to ‚Äúdo the right thing‚Äù and help save‚Ä¶ https://t.co/WRsIym8gbg

name: NPR
text:
As of Sunday, no mobile app store in the U.S. will be allowed to distribute or maintain TikTok or WeChat, the Commerce Department says.
https://t.co/ckWSlr5yHj

name: NPR
text:
Joe Biden continues to lead President Trump by a substantial margin: 9 points among likely voters, a new NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist poll finds.
https://t.co/koTyVF3PDf

name: NPR
text:
Efforts are growing to try to take police out of the response to people in a mental health crisis.

Critics and proponents alike say that a widely adopted police program creating Crisis Intervention Teams has too often failed.
https://t.co/5hEqrPqTLQ

name: NPR
text:
Exclusive: Days after it was revealed that D.C.'s top military police officer was looking for a "heat ray" to control protesters, NPR has learned a government watchdog has already opened an inquiry into federal tactics during the demonstrations.
https://t.co/JtkNojCwGd

name: NPR
text:
RT @nprmusic: "Justice for Breonna Taylor, a Kentuckian like me." 

To accompany the surprise release of his new album, Tyler Childers (@TTChilders) offers a message. 
https://t.co/tRzylOsUE5

name: NPR
text:
Whistleblowers say leadership at AGMA has cultivated a culture of secrecy.

They point to a real estate deal that could drain two-thirds of the union's financial reserves ‚Äî and a secretive, failed deal with disgraced opera star Pl√°cido Domingo.
https://t.co/ugapFz5DAt

name: NPR
text:
The people behind the Guinness World Records used to make money by selling books. But with the rise of the Internet, they had to create a new business model ‚Äî selling publicity.

Here's the story of how Guinness got into the business of record-breaking.
https://t.co/smJJKyGV3K

name: NPR
text:
President Trump on Friday claimed "every American" will have a coronavirus vaccine available by April. His own CDC director has said a vaccine likely would not be widely available until mid-2021.
https://t.co/u68miCKP96

name: NPR
text:
The Trump administration is promising nearly $13 billion in aid to rebuild Puerto Rico's electrical and education infrastructure ‚Äî 3 years after Hurricane Maria and just 6 weeks before the election.
https://t.co/peJAa1HNIF

name: NPR
text:
Guatemalan President Alejandro Giammattei has tested positive for the coronavirus and says he is "resting and isolating myself from all public activity."
https://t.co/Z7KYh8wkIu

name: NPR
text:
RT @npratc: With a world that's getting hotter, the costs of natural disasters are going up. But trying to change that could cost a lot, too. Today on #NPRConsiderThis, we look at the risks that come with energy sources with smaller carbon footprints.
https://t.co/MyKNZPGwwR

name: NPR
text:
BREAKING: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who charted a course for women‚Äôs rights at the U.S. Supreme Court and became a legal, cultural and feminist icon, has died from complications from cancer. She was 87.
https://t.co/3mOL0L0fUs
